reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s treatment of moral-uncertainty aggregation and suggests the ‘fussy views dominate / easygoingness unlikely’ takeaway depends on arbitrary normalization. This is somewhat central (the moral uncertainty section is part of the paper’s support for the ‘fussy/easygoing’ conclusion), but not fully central because the paper also argues for eutopian fragility and fussiness of many value functions without relying on intertheoretic aggregation. Strength is low because the paper already explicitly discusses multiple normalization methods (extinction–best, range, variance, pairwise), emphasizes that intertheoretic comparisons are thorny, and hedges its conclusions; so the critique partly attacks a position the paper does not actually hold (‘strictly fix scaling’ / ‘must recognize ambiguity’). Still, it is correct in the limited sense that aggregation choices can swing safety-vs-upside rankings and therefore can matter to how “dominant” fussy views appear in decision-making under moral uncertainty. The critique is clear, focused on a single issue, and contains little dead weight.
title: Arbitrary moral uncertainty aggregation conventions drive the dominance of fussy views
